reviewText: O, how I would like to buy this movie, but as with all the others from Warner Archive series there are NO subtitles. That,s the only reason for giving this movie 1 star instead of 5. I would be interested in a lot of other titles from this series if they had subtitles, Warner doesn't seem to care there are people who do have problems with hearing. I can follow the news in english but a movie where the actors often don't speak so clear is rather difficult. I wish Warner should give us a regular DVD in stead of DVD-R and I dont mind paying more for such a DVD.Ad de KoningHolland

reviewText: The immortal Spencer Tracy gives his typical solid performance as German George Heisler in Fred Zinnemann's unusual 1944 wartime drama "The Seventh Cross".It's 1936 and Germany is embarking on its Aryan philosophy by rounding up undesirables and interring them in concentration camps.  An embittered and mentally broken Tracy along with six others has escaped from the Westhof concentration camp.  They are planning to seek refuge from the underground in the nearby town of Mainz.  Dutiful and ruthless camp commandant Fahrenberg nicely played by George Zucco vows to crucify each captured escapee on crosses erected for that purpose in the camp courtyard.The others are quickly captured but Tracy relying on the kindness of strangers and a network of sympathetic Germans is  shuttled from place to place evading capture.  The movie contains excellent performances by Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy as a married couple and former friends of Tracy who are not totally sold on the Nazi philosophy.  Agnes Moorehead plays a compassionate theatre costumer who also aids Tracy in his quest.Tracy eventually winds up in an inn in which Signe Hasso works as a beer maid.  She hides him from the Gestapo and they fall into a very brief love, which was a trifle overacted.  Tracy is forced to flee to an awaiting ship, which will transport him to Holland.What makes "The Seventh Cross" so unique is that while it was created in 1944 it is not a typical propagandized wartime movie.  The common German people, unsympathetic to the mindless jackbooted philosophies of Hitler are heraldedand portrayed as warm, compassionate people.  We sometimes fail to realize that not everyone was swayed by Nazi philosophy and this movie adroitly points that out.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Boy, this a grim story, but it gets you involved, especially if you tend to be a bit paranoid. The story centers around Spencer Tracy's character "George Heisler" hiding from the Nazis in 1936 Germany, not knowing who to trust.Although there's not much action, this is decently-paced with an unusual (and too corny) narrative from a dead man. The last 20 minutes, which should have been the most suspenseful of the film, instead wound up boring and too melodramatic.What I did find interesting was the very young couple of Jessica Tandy and husband Hume Cronyn. I had forgotten what a beautiful woman Tandy was when she was young. She and Hume were the best part of this film. Tracy, meanwhile, doesn't have a lot of dialog.The movie paints a horrible picture of pre-World War II Germany. There are several attempts to lift the spirits of the viewer as he watches this but overall it is a grim story of survival
summary: Tandy & Croyn Brighten Up Grim Story

reviewText: Seventh Cross" came out in 1944 and was one of the first films to discuss concentration camps - "Night Train to Munich" (1940) and "All Through the Night" (1941) were probably the first films to address this issue, although they did it peripherally while the "Seventh Cross" actually deals with the conditions of imprisonment. The film takes place in1936 and involves the escape from a camp by seven German citizens (writer, farmer, circus performer, school master, clerk, mechanic and a political activist).Most of the focus is on the escape of Spencer Tracy (1900-1967). Tracy is ranked 9th among AFI's Greatest Male Stars. He won 2 Oscars ("Captains Courageous" in 1937 and "Boys Town" in 1938) and was nominated 7 more times. Personally I think his best performances were "Inherit the Wind" (1960) and "Judgment at Nuremberg" (1961). His acting method was - "Come to work on time, know your lines and don't bump into the other actors."Hume Cronyn (1911-2003) plays an old friend of Tracy. He was nominated for an Oscar for this film but lost to Barry Fitzgerald ("Going My Way"). He had 7 Emmy nominations and 3 wins ("To Dance with the White Dog", "Broadway Bound", "Age Old Friends") but is probably best known for "Cocoon" (1985).Jessica Tandy (1909-94) plays Cronyn's wife. This was the first time the real life husband and wife appeared on screen as a married couple, and this was also Tandy's first American film. Tandy is best known for her Oscar winning performance in "Driving Miss Daisy" (1989)Agnes Morehead (1900-74) earned 4 Academy Award nominations ("Hush Hush Sweet Charlotte", "Johnny Belinda", "Mrs. Parkington", Magnificent Ambersons"), along with 6 Emmy nominations for her role in "Bewitched" and a win for a role in "Wild Wild West" (1965). She won two Golden Globes. Morehead befriends Tracey at a critical time.Ray Collins (1889-1965) plays the organizer of the prison escape, and he narrates the film. He appeared in "Citizen Kane" (1941), "Magnificent Ambersons" (1942) and did a great job as the DA in "Touch of Evil" (1958) which was his last film before moving to TV where he appeared as Lt. Tragg on "Perry Mason".BTW - Morehead and Collins were both members of Orson Welles' players and appeared together in several films the most notable of which was "The Magnificent Ambersons" (1942).George Macready (1899-1973) plays a wealthy architect who used to be involved in anti-Nazi discussions, but out of fear has left all that behind him until he is approached to help Tracy. Macready was a marvelous actor, usually playing sophisticated villains in films like "Gilda" and "Paths of Glory" (1957). He may be best known for his years on TV's "Peyton Place" as old man Peyton. This was his third film.This was the first of 25 films for Director Fred Zinnermann (1907-97) who won the Oscar 3 times ("A Man for all Seasons", "From Here to Eternity", "Benjy") and gave us such memorable films as "High Noon" (1952), "Julia" (1977) and "The Day of the Jackal" (1973). Over his career, 18 actors were nominated for Oscars after appearing in one of his films. He said "I believe in making films that will please a mass audience, and not just in making films that express my own personality or ideas. I have always tried to offer an audience something positive in a film and to entertain them as well."Cinematographer Karl Freund (1890-1969) does a terrific job using his camera to reinforce the foreboding and claustrophobic feeling of the script. Freund won an Oscar for "The Good Earth" (1937) and has the distinction of being nominated twice in a single year (1941) for a color ("Blossoms in the Dust") and a black & white ("The Chocolate Soldier") film. Freund worked with German expressionists F. W. Murnau and Fritz Lang and filmed such classics as "Golem" (1920), "The Last Laugh" (1924), and "Metropolis" (1927), and their influence is apparent in Freund's use of shadows and angles in this film. His other film credits include "Dracula" (1931), "Murders in the Rue Morgue" (1932), and "Pride and Prejudice" (1940). It was Freund who developed the 3-camera film shooting introduced in the TV series "I Love Lucy" which became the standard for all TV shows ever since.The musical score from Roy Webb (1888-1982) is excellent, a great example of how music can supplement the story without imposing. Webb is best known from his work with Val Lewton, though he worked on more than 200 films and was nominated for an Oscar 6 times between 1938 and 1946.Pandro Berman (1905-96) produced for RKO. Berman was to RKO what Irving Thalberg was to MGM. Under his careful eye RKO produced such classics as "The Gay Divorcee" (1934), "Of Human Bondage" (1934), "Alice Adams" (1935), "Top Hat" (1935), "Stage Door" (1937), "Hunchback of Notre Dame" (1939), and "Gunga Din" (1939). Six of his films earned Oscars for Best Picture.The NY Times' Bosley Crowther called the film "absorbing" and praised the "crackling tension and hard-packed realism." He said Tracy "gives a splendid performance", Cronyn is "splendidly bourgeois" and Tandy "is emotionally devastating."While this is a very good film it is not without its flaws. Almost the entire film is shot on sets, even the outdoor scenes, and it's evident. The script calls for many comments about the hunger of the convicts and people keep telling Tracy that he looks thin and/or sick or "beaten to a hollow hulk", but in fact Tracy has his usual extra few pounds on him and hardly looks hungry, thin, or sick.The film also has problems with the timeline. It was made in 1944 but set in 1936, and the concentration camp atmosphere they describe is not really what was going on in 1936. There is talk of "slaughter" and "butchery" which is certainly true of camps after 1939, but not in 1936.This is also a funny story to come out in 1944. It might have been more appropriate after the war. The whole point of the film is that Tracy is looking for an ounce of decency in the German people, and while he doesn't find it in the first part of the film, in the second half of the film a whole bunch of people come to his aide. So not every German is a Nazi and just as there is hope for Tracy, there is hope for Germany. Most films before the end of the war were far harsher toward the German people.This is a great film, not only for the acting and the message, but all the elements come together to make the film itself a real treat.PS - The title of my review comes from a comment by a nameless man who helps Tracy. He is a grocer and tells Tracy that a army of little ants manage to move the sugar from his shelf, and his role is to be a little ant and together with all the other decent people, they will prevail.

reviewText: This film has now been released by Warner Archive and I reccomend that anyone who loves classic film should buy it. It is a gripping, suspenseful story of the kind that just isn't made anymore, which vividly evokes the horror and paranoia of life in a brutal, totalitarian state.The first thing that struck me was the beautiful, deep-focus photography by Karl Freund, one of the brilliant German immigrants who so influenced American cinema. Then there is the huge list of character actors. (One of the things woefully missing in modern film is the character actor.) There is Agnes Moorehead, George Zucco, Jessica Tandy, (no longer a headliner at this point) Hume Croynin and many others. The list of characters is is about 100 long. And Hume Croynin, remarkably, plays a good guy in this one. It is rather amazing to me that this hasn't had a release to regular dvd. It just goes to show how many treasures are rotting away on studio shelves. A word of warning though, this film is somewhat depressing and bleak. Biss-ninnies may want to watch The Sound Of Music instead.
Title: N/A

reviewText: 3 1/2 stars. This early Fred Zinnemann effort takes a humanistic look at pre-war Nazi Germany. It avoids the "lets all hate the Germans" stance of other war films of the early forties and while it shows evil  Germans it also shows Germans whose innate decency compels them to aid the  hero who is on the run from the Gestapo. Tracy, with minimal dialogue,  gives a fine, intense performance. There is good work , too, from Hume  Cronyn and Jessica Tandy. Zinnemann conveys considerable suspense as well  as a completely believable European ambience.
summary: Suspenseful and unusual World War II film

reviewText: Seven men escaped from Westhofen, but just one of them George Heissler will surmount all the obstacles to find  at last, to materialize this dream.This movie tells us about the multiple difficulties that George will have to feat in order to survive. Struggling and absorbing episode based on real facts in Germany 1936, when dissent was already considered a serious evidence of sedition and betrayal against the totalitarian state.Impeccable acting of Spencer Tracy and fine direction of Fred Zinnemman.

reviewText: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM) presents "SEVENTH CROSS" (1944  110 min/B&W;) -- Starring: Spencer Tracy, Signe Hasso, Hume Cronyn, Jessica Tandy & Agnes MooreheadDirected by Fred ZinnemannFred Zinnemann directed this World War II drama, considered one of the best anti-Nazi dramas produced by Hollywood during the war years. The story concerns seven prisoners in a Nazi concentration camp who manage to elude the guards and the Gestapo. The commandant, in a rage over their escape, nails crosses to seven trees, planning to crucify each of the prisoners as they are captured. Gradually six of the prisoners are discovered by the Gestapo and crucified. The one remaining escapee, George Heisler (Spencer Tracy), has become embittered and cynical after his years in the concentration camp. But as an assortment of friends and strangers help him elude the Gestapo, Heisler heads for neutral Holland, his faith in mankind restored.Jessica Tandy had her first screen appearance as Liesel Roeder, the wife of Paul Roeder (Hume Cronyn, Tandy's real life husband), one of the friends who helps Heisler make his way to freedomGreat Direction, Cast, Screenplay and Music, all around great film.Hume Cronyn was Oscar nominated his role here (Supporting Actor)BIOS:1. Signe Hasso  [aka: Signe Eleonora Cecilia Larsson]Date of Birth:  15 August 1910 - Stockholm, SwedenDate of Death:  7 June 2002 - Los Angeles, California4. Jessica TandyDate of Birth:  7 June 1909 - Stoke Newington, London, England, UKDate of Death:  11 September 1994 - Easton, Connecticut6. Ray CollinsDate of Birth:  10 December 1889 - Sacramento, CaliforniaDate of Death:  11 July 1965 - Santa Monica, CaliforniaMr. Jim's Ratings:Quality of Picture & Sound: 5 StarsPerformance: 5 StarsStory & Screenplay: 5 StarsOverall: 5 Stars [Original Music, Cinematography & Film Editing]Total Time: 110 min on DVD/VHS ~ Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM  ~ (September 1, 1998)

reviewText: "The Seventh Cross" is a gritty, uneven, some what pretentious and yet powerful film depicting one man's escape and spiritual redemption from the mental and physical horrors of incarceration as a political prisoner in a concentration camp in Nazi Germany - circa 1936. The movie begins with a desperate escape by seven political prisoners from the Westoffen concentration camp and the subsequent manhunt will eventually net six of them who are then mercilessly tortured for information and hung on crosses in the main yard of the camp. The brutal camp commandant, Farenburgh {George Zucco} has made a vow to put the final corpse on "The Seventh Cross" - a promise he means to keep!!George Heisler {Spencer Tracy} a patriotic decent man that has been mentally broken/brutalized into a man akin to "the walking dead" and as the final escapee still at large - begins a roller coaster cross country trek to the city of Mainz where he may find help from a anti-Nazi resistance cell led by one Rudolph Shink at 46 William Strass if  Heslier can be guided to them. However can he find them? Can they find him? Can they even be trusted "a big if"!!  Heisler's dilemma is - Who can he go to for help? Have his former colleagues and friends been turned into slavish supporters of the Nazi state?  Can his fellow escapees "Fuellengrabe" {Konstantine Shayne}and "Bellaini" {George Suzanne} even be trusted not to betray him ? How about his ex-fiance "Leni" {Karen Verne}? In his trek across country to get to Mainz, hunted at every turn Heisler will find out this {and much more} and his stoic, furtive, personna will gradually emerge from it's mental incarceration and become the stalward, decisive man that he was prior to his "hell stay" at Westoffen.This is an "A Class" MGM production for which no expense was spared,  particlarily in assembling a superb supporting cast of terrific character actors. Hume Cronyn {Paul Roeder},Jessica Tandy {Liesel Roeder},George McCReady {Bruno Sauer}, Felix Bressart,{Poldi Schalman}, Steve Garay {Doctor Loenstein}, Herbert Rudley {Frank Marnet} and Signe Hasso {Toni} are shown "warts and all" as venal opportunists, self sacrificing patriots, hero's and cowards that Heisler is now blindly going to have to seek out and risk his freedom on some/all of them to trust. Ray Collins {Ernest Wallau} and Agnes Morehead {Mme Marelli} are particularily outstanding with Ms Morehead playing a theatrical costumer who {apparently} is completely obvilious to the politics, persecutions and evils happening outside of her shop which could turn out to be a very improbable stroke of luck for Heisler - maybe !!.Spencer Tracy gives an outstanding performance and it's excellence is a large part based on the expressive pantomine of his face and body - on how his eyes, facial expressions and body language register the fear, loathing, hate, rage, horror, relief and resolution that Heisler has to internalize to survive. Tracey's subtle understated performance is {in my opinion} one of the best of his career. This movie's main theme is not the escape, it how George and some of his fellow Germans rediscover their faith, courage and regroup within themselves to find redemption - that despite travails of men and women who the Nazi state attempts to control, spied on, face informants and possible betrayal from their fellow citizens - the will in them to survive and to fight for freedom against oppression will ultimately prevail. This is what the 1944 movie audience expected to see and truly believed in - that the Nazi's and Japanese as "evil's" had to be confronted and defeated regardless of the cost.Director Fred Zimmemann keeps a tight rein on the actors and he ensures there is no overacting or mock heroic gestures - the actors/actresses are all uniformly excellent. The movies production values are outstanding with Karl Freud's camera work and Cedric Gibbons art direction are {as usual} first rate. This is an outstanding example of MGM product - cast, acting, production values and direction and I give it a 4 1/2 star rating.
summary: Intense Melodrama of German Pre-War Resistance to Nazi Oppression with a Riveting Performance by Spencer Tracy:

reviewText: This is a good WWII vintage movie that makes a sombre and serous attempt to explore the captive mind of Fascism.  It stars Spencer Tracy as one of seven concentration camps escapees in Germany.  The commandant has sworn that he will nail each of the escapees to the seven crosses he has made.  The bulk of the movie focusses on George Heisler (Tracy's character) and his efforts to find someone on the outside he can trust to help him.  One by one the crosses are filled and Heisler's search becomes more and more desperate and depressing.  No one seems to want to stick their neck out and help him.  In time, things reach a crisis point and, in the midst of dispair, hope and trust appear.  The movie becomes an uplifting message that transcends that of the typical WWII era movies.Initially I reacted somewhat negatively to the narrow scope of the movie.  After all, making the audience uncomfortable about the intended death of seven concentration camp inmates seemed to miss the point of the horrors that those camps hosted.  However, upon reflection, I realized that the better message was that of responsibility rather than that of horror.  This film conveys a timelessness in its' statement that is hard not to appreciate.  That it has drifted into obscurity is unfortunate.

reviewText: The film was released in 1944, as D-Day in Europe was making a beginning to the end of WW2. Its central proposition is this: how can we bring ourselves ever again to trust and respect a German? Quite a handful for a Hollywood production! The story is simple enough: will the last of seven escapees from a German concentration camp in 1936 make it to freedom? The suspense is well manipulated by director Fred Zinnemann, employing a quality cast and all his considerable film-making skills. Some viewers may find the voiceover narrative and the structure of the story heavy-handed and propagandistic, but you have to consider the times. When you think of what this film attempts to say, in the depths of 'total war', it must be respected. The story, in any case, is well told and the  picture retains a great deal of interest.
Title: N/A
